texts.orig: ( ii ) in the case of a female, a person under eighteen years of age.]
texts.text: ( ii ) in the case of a female, a person under eighteen years of age.]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 364. Kidnapping or abducting in order to murder . -Whoever kidnaps or abducts any person in order  that  such  person  may  be  murdered  or  may  be  so  disposed  of  as  to  be  put  in  danger  of  being murdered, shall be punished with 3 [imprisonment for life] or rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
texts.text: Kidnapping or abducting in order to murder . -Whoever kidnaps or abducts any person in order  that  such  person  may  be  murdered  or  may  be  so  disposed  of  as  to  be  put  in  danger  of  being murdered, shall be punished with 3 [imprisonment for life] or rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: IIIustrations
texts.text: IIIustrations

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( a ) A kidnaps Z from 1 [India], intending or knowing it to be likely that Z may be sacrificed to an idol. A has committed the offence defined in this section.
texts.text: ( a ) A kidnaps Z from 1 [India], intending or knowing it to be likely that Z may be sacrificed to an idol. A has committed the offence defined in this section.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( b )  A  forcibly  carries  or  entices  B  away  from  his  home  in  order  that  B  may  be  murdered.  A  has  committed  the  offence defined in this section.
texts.text: ( b )  A  forcibly  carries  or  entices  B  away  from  his  home  in  order  that  B  may  be  murdered.  A  has  committed  the  offence defined in this section.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: 4 [364A. Kidnapping for ransom, etc . -Whoever kidnaps or abducts any person or keeps a person in detention after such kidnapping or abduction, and threatens to cause death or hurt to such person, or by his conduct gives rise to a reasonable apprehension that such person may be put to death or hurt, or causes hurt or death to such person in order to compel the Government or 5 [any foreign State or international inter-governmental  organisation  or  any  other  person]  to  do  or  abstain  from  doing  any  act  or  to  pay  a ransom, shall be punishable with death, or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.]
texts.text: 4 [364A. Kidnapping for ransom, etc . -Whoever kidnaps or abducts any person or keeps a person in detention after such kidnapping or abduction, and threatens to cause death or hurt to such person, or by his conduct gives rise to a reasonable apprehension that such person may be put to death or hurt, or causes hurt or death to such person in order to compel the Government or 5 [any foreign State or international inter-governmental  organisation  or  any  other  person]  to  do  or  abstain  from  doing  any  act  or  to  pay  a ransom, shall be punishable with death, or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.]

texts.label: text
texts.orig: 365. Kidnapping or abducting with intent secretly and wrongfully to confine person . -Whoever kidnaps or abducts any person with intent to cause that person to be secretly and wrongfully confined, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
texts.text: 365. Kidnapping or abducting with intent secretly and wrongfully to confine person . -Whoever kidnaps or abducts any person with intent to cause that person to be secretly and wrongfully confined, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: 366. Kidnapping, abducting or inducing woman to compel her marriage, etc . -Whoever kidnaps or abducts any woman with intent that she may be compelled, or knowing it to be likely that she will be compelled, to marry any person against her will, or in order that she may be forced or seduced to illicit intercourse, or knowing it to be likely that she will be forced or seduced to illicit intercourse, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine; 1 [and whoever, by means of criminal intimidation as defined in this Code or of abuse of authority or any other method of compulsion, induces any woman to go from any place with intent that she  may  be,  or  knowing  that  it  is  likely  that  she  will  be,  forced  or  seduced  to  illicit  intercourse  with another person shall also be punishable as aforesaid].
texts.text: 366. Kidnapping, abducting or inducing woman to compel her marriage, etc . -Whoever kidnaps or abducts any woman with intent that she may be compelled, or knowing it to be likely that she will be compelled, to marry any person against her will, or in order that she may be forced or seduced to illicit intercourse, or knowing it to be likely that she will be forced or seduced to illicit intercourse, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine; 1 [and whoever, by means of criminal intimidation as defined in this Code or of abuse of authority or any other method of compulsion, induces any woman to go from any place with intent that she  may  be,  or  knowing  that  it  is  likely  that  she  will  be,  forced  or  seduced  to  illicit  intercourse  with another person shall also be punishable as aforesaid].

texts.label: text
texts.orig: 2 [ 366A. Procuration of minor girl . -Whoever, by any means whatsoever, induces any minor girl under the age of eighteen years to go from any place or to do any act with intent that such girl may be, or knowing that it is likely that she will be, forced or seduced to illicit intercourse with another person shall be punishable with imprisonment which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
texts.text: 2 [ 366A. Procuration of minor girl . -Whoever, by any means whatsoever, induces any minor girl under the age of eighteen years to go from any place or to do any act with intent that such girl may be, or knowing that it is likely that she will be, forced or seduced to illicit intercourse with another person shall be punishable with imprisonment which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: 366B. Importation of girl from foreign country . -Whoever imports into 3 [India] from any country outside India 4 [or from the State of Jammu and Kashmir] any girl under the age of twenty-one years with intent that she may be, or knowing it to be likely that she will be, forced or seduced to illicit intercourse with another person, 5 *** shall be punishable with imprisonment which may extend to ten years and shall shall also be liable to fine.]
texts.text: 366B. Importation of girl from foreign country . -Whoever imports into 3 [India] from any country outside India 4 [or from the State of Jammu and Kashmir] any girl under the age of twenty-one years with intent that she may be, or knowing it to be likely that she will be, forced or seduced to illicit intercourse with another person, 5 *** shall be punishable with imprisonment which may extend to ten years and shall shall also be liable to fine.]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 367.  Kidnapping  or  abducting  in  order  to  subject  person  to  grievous  hurt,  slavery,  etc . -Whoever  kidnaps  or  abducts  any  person  in  order  that  such  person  may  be  subjected,  or  may  be  so disposed of as to be put in danger of being subjected to grievous hurt, or slavery, or to the unnatural lust of any person, or knowing it to be likely that such person will be so subjected or  disposed of, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
texts.text: Kidnapping  or  abducting  in  order  to  subject  person  to  grievous  hurt,  slavery,  etc . -Whoever  kidnaps  or  abducts  any  person  in  order  that  such  person  may  be  subjected,  or  may  be  so disposed of as to be put in danger of being subjected to grievous hurt, or slavery, or to the unnatural lust of any person, or knowing it to be likely that such person will be so subjected or  disposed of, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 368.  Wrongfully  concealing  or  keeping  in  confinement,  kidnapped  or  abducted  person . -Whoever, knowing that any person has been kidnapped or has been abducted, wrongfully conceals or confines  such  person,  shall  be  punished  in  the  same  manner  as  if  he  had  kidnapped  or  abducted  such person  with  the  same  intention  or  knowledge,  or  for  the  same  purpose  as  that  with  or  for  which  he conceals or detains such person in confinement.
texts.text: Wrongfully  concealing  or  keeping  in  confinement,  kidnapped  or  abducted  person . -Whoever, knowing that any person has been kidnapped or has been abducted, wrongfully conceals or confines  such  person,  shall  be  punished  in  the  same  manner  as  if  he  had  kidnapped  or  abducted  such person  with  the  same  intention  or  knowledge,  or  for  the  same  purpose  as  that  with  or  for  which  he conceals or detains such person in confinement.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: 369.  Kidnapping  or  abducting  child  under  ten  years  with  intent  to  steal  from  its  person . -Whoever kidnaps or abducts any child under the age of ten years with the intention of taking dishonestly any  movable  property  from  the  person  of  such  child,  shall  be  punished  with  imprisonment  of  either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
texts.text: 369.  Kidnapping  or  abducting  child  under  ten  years  with  intent  to  steal  from  its  person . -Whoever kidnaps or abducts any child under the age of ten years with the intention of taking dishonestly any  movable  property  from  the  person  of  such  child,  shall  be  punished  with  imprisonment  of  either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

texts.text: Sixthly. -by inducement, including the giving or receiving of payments or benefits, in order to achieve the consent of any person having control overthe person recruited, transported, harboured, transferred or received, commits the offence of trafficking.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Explanation 1. -The expression "exploitation" shall include any act of physical exploitation or any form of sexual exploitation, slavery or practices similar to slavery, servitude, or the forced removal of organs.
texts.text: Explanation 1. -The expression "exploitation" shall include any act of physical exploitation or any form of sexual exploitation, slavery or practices similar to slavery, servitude, or the forced removal of organs.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Explanation  2. -The consent  of  the  victim  is  immaterial  in  determination  of  the  offence  of trafficking.
texts.text: Explanation  2. -The consent  of  the  victim  is  immaterial  in  determination  of  the  offence  of trafficking.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: (2) Whoever commits the offence of trafficking shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than seven years, but which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
texts.text: Whoever commits the offence of trafficking shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than seven years, but which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( 3 ) Where the offence involves the trafficking of more than one person, it shall be punishable with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than ten years but which may extend to imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.
texts.text: ( 3 ) Where the offence involves the trafficking of more than one person, it shall be punishable with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than ten years but which may extend to imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( 4 ) Where the offence involves the trafficking of a minor, it shall be punishable with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than ten years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.
texts.text: ( 4 ) Where the offence involves the trafficking of a minor, it shall be punishable with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than ten years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( 5 )  Where the offence involves the trafficking of more than one minor, it shall be punishable with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than fourteen years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.
texts.text: ( 5 )  Where the offence involves the trafficking of more than one minor, it shall be punishable with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than fourteen years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( 6 ) If a person is convicted of the offence of trafficking of minor on more than one occasion, then such  person  shall  be  punished  with  imprisonment  for  life,  which  shall  mean  imprisonment  for  the remainder of that person's natural life, and shall also be liable to fine.
texts.text: ( 6 ) If a person is convicted of the offence of trafficking of minor on more than one occasion, then such  person  shall  be  punished  with  imprisonment  for  life,  which  shall  mean  imprisonment  for  the remainder of that person's natural life, and shall also be liable to fine.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( 7 ) When a public servant or a police officer is involved in the trafficking of any person then, such public  servant  or  police  officer  shall  be  punished  with  imprisonment  for  life,  which  shall  mean imprisonment for the remainder of that person's natural life, and shall also be liable to fine.
texts.text: ( 7 ) When a public servant or a police officer is involved in the trafficking of any person then, such public  servant  or  police  officer  shall  be  punished  with  imprisonment  for  life,  which  shall  mean imprisonment for the remainder of that person's natural life, and shall also be liable to fine.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 370A. Exploitation of a trafficked person. -( 1 )  Whoever, knowingly or having reason to believe that  a  minor  has  been  trafficked,  engages  such  minor  for  sexual  exploitation  in  any  manner,  shall  be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than five years, but which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
texts.text: 370A. Exploitation of a trafficked person. -( 1 )  Whoever, knowingly or having reason to believe that  a  minor  has  been  trafficked,  engages  such  minor  for  sexual  exploitation  in  any  manner,  shall  be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than five years, but which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( 2 )  Whoever, knowingly by or having reason to believe that a person has been trafficked, engages such person for sexual exploitation in any manner, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than three years, but which may extend to five years, and shall also be liable to fine.]
texts.text: ( 2 )  Whoever, knowingly by or having reason to believe that a person has been trafficked, engages such person for sexual exploitation in any manner, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than three years, but which may extend to five years, and shall also be liable to fine.]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 371. Habitual dealing in slaves . -Whoever habitually imports, exports, removes, buys, sells, traffics or  deals  in  slaves,  shall  be  punished  with 1 [imprisonment  for  life],  or  with  imprisonment  of  either description for a term not exceeding ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
texts.text: Habitual dealing in slaves . -Whoever habitually imports, exports, removes, buys, sells, traffics or  deals  in  slaves,  shall  be  punished  with 1 [imprisonment  for  life],  or  with  imprisonment  of  either description for a term not exceeding ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

texts.orig: Explanation  II . -For  the  purposes  of  this  section ' illicit  intercourse ' means  sexual  intercourse between  persons  not  united  by  marriage  or  by  any  union  or  tie  which,  though  not  amounting  to  a marriage, is recognised by the personal law or custom of the community to which they belong or, where they belong to different communities, of both such communities, as constituting between them a quasi -marital relation.]

texts.orig: 374. Unlawful compulsory labour . -Whoever unlawfully compels any person to labour against the will  of  that  person,  shall  be  punished  with  imprisonment  of  either  description  for  a  term  which  may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.
texts.text: 374. Unlawful compulsory labour . -Whoever unlawfully compels any person to labour against the will  of  that  person,  shall  be  punished  with  imprisonment  of  either  description  for  a  term  which  may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 376A.  Punishment  for  causing  death  or  resulting  in  persistent  vegetative  state  of  victim . -Whoever, commits an offence punishable under sub-section ( 1 ) or sub-section ( 2 ) of section 376 and in the  course  of  such  commission  inflicts  an  injury  which  causes  the  death  of  the  woman  or  causes  the woman to be in a persistent vegetative state, shall be punished with rigorous  imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than twenty years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life, which shall mean imprisonment for the remainder of that person's natural life, or with death.
texts.text: 376A.  Punishment  for  causing  death  or  resulting  in  persistent  vegetative  state  of  victim . -Whoever, commits an offence punishable under sub-section ( 1 ) or sub-section ( 2 ) of section 376 and in the  course  of  such  commission  inflicts  an  injury  which  causes  the  death  of  the  woman  or  causes  the woman to be in a persistent vegetative state, shall be punished with rigorous  imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than twenty years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life, which shall mean imprisonment for the remainder of that person's natural life, or with death.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 376B.  Sexual  intercourse  by  husband  upon  his  wife  during  separation . -Whoever  has  sexual intercourse  with  his  own  wife,  who  is  living  separately,  whether  under  a  decree  of  separation  or otherwise,  without  her  consent,  shall  be  punished  with  imprisonment  of  either  description  for  a  term which shall not be less than two years but which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
texts.text: 376B.  Sexual  intercourse  by  husband  upon  his  wife  during  separation . -Whoever  has  sexual intercourse  with  his  own  wife,  who  is  living  separately,  whether  under  a  decree  of  separation  or otherwise,  without  her  consent,  shall  be  punished  with  imprisonment  of  either  description  for  a  term which shall not be less than two years but which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Explanation . -In this section, ' sexual intercourse ' shall mean any of the acts mentioned in clauses ( a ) to ( d ) of section 375.

texts.text: ( a ) in a position of authority or in a fiduciary relationship; or

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( b ) a public servant; or
texts.text: ( b ) a public servant; or

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( c ) superintendent or manager of a jail, remand home or other place of custody established by or under any law for the time being in force, or a women's or children's institution; or
texts.text: ( c ) superintendent or manager of a jail, remand home or other place of custody established by or under any law for the time being in force, or a women's or children's institution; or

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( d ) on the management of a hospital or being on the staff of a hospital,
texts.text: ( d ) on the management of a hospital or being on the staff of a hospital,

texts.label: text
texts.orig: abuses such position or fiduciary relationship to induce or seduce any woman either in his custody or under his charge or present in the premises to have sexual intercourse with him, such sexual intercourse not amounting to the offence of rape, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than five years, but which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
texts.text: abuses such position or fiduciary relationship to induce or seduce any woman either in his custody or under his charge or present in the premises to have sexual intercourse with him, such sexual intercourse not amounting to the offence of rape, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than five years, but which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Explanation 1. -In  this  section, ' sexual  intercourse ' shall  mean  any  of  the  acts  mentioned  in clauses ( a ) to ( d ) of section 375.
texts.text: Explanation 1. -In  this  section, ' sexual  intercourse ' shall  mean  any  of  the  acts  mentioned  in clauses ( a ) to ( d ) of section 375.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Explanation 2. -For  the  purposes  of  this  section, Explanation 1  to  section  375  shall  also  be applicable.
texts.text: Explanation 2. -For  the  purposes  of  this  section, Explanation 1  to  section  375  shall  also  be applicable.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Explanation 3. -' Superintendent ' , in relation to a jail, remand home or other place of custody or a  women's or children's institution, includes a person holding any other office in such jail, remand
texts.text: Explanation 3. -' Superintendent ' , in relation to a jail, remand home or other place of custody or a  women's or children's institution, includes a person holding any other office in such jail, remand

texts.label: text
texts.orig: home, place or institution by virtue of which such person can exercise any authority or control over its inmates.
texts.text: home, place or institution by virtue of which such person can exercise any authority or control over its inmates.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Explanation 4. -The  expressions ' hospital '  and  ' wo men's  or children's institution' shall respectively have the same meaning as in Explanation to sub-section ( 2 ) of section 376.
texts.text: Explanation 4. -The  expressions ' hospital '  and  ' wo men's  or children's institution' shall respectively have the same meaning as in Explanation to sub-section ( 2 ) of section 376.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: 376D. Gang rape . -Where a woman is raped by one or more persons constituting a group or acting in  furtherance  of  a  common  intention,  each  of  those  persons  shall  be  deemed  to  have  committed  the offence of rape and shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than twenty  years,  but  which  may  extend  to  life  which  shall  mean  imprisonment  for  the  remainder  of  that person's natural life, and with fine:
texts.text: 376D. Gang rape . -Where a woman is raped by one or more persons constituting a group or acting in  furtherance  of  a  common  intention,  each  of  those  persons  shall  be  deemed  to  have  committed  the offence of rape and shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than twenty  years,  but  which  may  extend  to  life  which  shall  mean  imprisonment  for  the  remainder  of  that person's natural life, and with fine:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Provided that such fine shall be just and reasonable to meet the medical expenses and rehabilitation of the victim:
texts.text: Provided that such fine shall be just and reasonable to meet the medical expenses and rehabilitation of the victim:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Provided further that any fine imposed under this section shall be paid to the victim.
texts.text: Provided further that any fine imposed under this section shall be paid to the victim.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 376E. Punishment for repeat offenders . -Whoever has been previously convicted of an offence punishable  under  section  376  or  section  376A  or  section  376D  and  is  subsequently  convicted  of  an offence punishable under any of the said sections shall be punished with imprisonment for life which shall mean imprisonment for the remainder of that person's natural life, or with death.]]
texts.text: 376E. Punishment for repeat offenders . -Whoever has been previously convicted of an offence punishable  under  section  376  or  section  376A  or  section  376D  and  is  subsequently  convicted  of  an offence punishable under any of the said sections shall be punished with imprisonment for life which shall mean imprisonment for the remainder of that person's natural life, or with death.]]

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Of Unnatural Offences
texts.text: Of Unnatural Offences

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 377. Unnatural offences . -Whoever voluntarily has carnal intercourse against the order of nature with any man, woman or animal, shall be punished with 1 [imprisonment for life], or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
texts.text: Unnatural offences . -Whoever voluntarily has carnal intercourse against the order of nature with any man, woman or animal, shall be punished with 1 [imprisonment for life], or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Explanation . -Penetration is sufficient to constitute the carnal intercourse necessary to the offence described in this section.
texts.text: Explanation . -Penetration is sufficient to constitute the carnal intercourse necessary to the offence described in this section.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: CHAPTER XVII
texts.text: CHAPTER XVII

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: OF OFFENCESAGAINST PROPERTY
texts.text: OF OFFENCESAGAINST PROPERTY

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Of Theft
texts.text: Of Theft

texts.label: text
texts.orig: 378. Theft . -Whoever, intending to take dishonestly any movable property out of the possession of any person without that person's consent, moves that property in order to such taking, is said to commit theft.
texts.text: 378. Theft . -Whoever, intending to take dishonestly any movable property out of the possession of any person without that person's consent, moves that property in order to such taking, is said to commit theft.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Explanation 1 . -A thing so long as it is attached to the earth, not being movable property, is not the subject of theft; but it becomes capable of being the subject of theft as soon as it is severed from the earth.
texts.text: Explanation 1 . -A thing so long as it is attached to the earth, not being movable property, is not the subject of theft; but it becomes capable of being the subject of theft as soon as it is severed from the earth.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Explanation 2 . -A moving effected by the same act which effects the severance may be a theft.
texts.text: Explanation 2 . -A moving effected by the same act which effects the severance may be a theft.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Explanation 3 . -A person is said to cause a thing to move by removing an obstacle which prevented it from moving or by separating it from any other thing, as well as by actually moving it.
texts.text: Explanation 3 . -A person is said to cause a thing to move by removing an obstacle which prevented it from moving or by separating it from any other thing, as well as by actually moving it.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Explanation 4 . -A person, who by any means causes an animal to move, is said to move that animal, and to move everything which, in consequence of the motion so caused, is moved by that animal.
texts.text: Explanation 4 . -A person, who by any means causes an animal to move, is said to move that animal, and to move everything which, in consequence of the motion so caused, is moved by that animal.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Explanation  5 . -The  consent  mentioned  in  the  definition  may  be  express  or  implied,  and  may  be given either by the person in possession, or by any person having for that purpose authority either express or implied.
texts.text: Explanation  5 . -The  consent  mentioned  in  the  definition  may  be  express  or  implied,  and  may  be given either by the person in possession, or by any person having for that purpose authority either express or implied.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Illustrations
texts.text: Illustrations

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( a )  A  cuts  down  a  tree  on  Z's  ground,  with  the intention of  dishonestly  taking  the  tree  out  of  Z's  possession  without  Z's consent. Here, as soon as A has severed the tree in order to such taking, he has committed theft.
texts.text: ( a )  A  cuts  down  a  tree  on  Z's  ground,  with  the intention of  dishonestly  taking  the  tree  out  of  Z's  possession  without  Z's consent. Here, as soon as A has severed the tree in order to such taking, he has committed theft.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( b ) A puts a bait for dogs in his pocket, and thus induces Z's dog to follow it. Here, if A's intention be dishonestly to take the dog out of Z's possession without Z's consent, A has committed theft as soon as Z's dog has begun to follow A.
texts.text: ( b ) A puts a bait for dogs in his pocket, and thus induces Z's dog to follow it. Here, if A's intention be dishonestly to take the dog out of Z's possession without Z's consent, A has committed theft as soon as Z's dog has begun to follow A.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( c )  A  meets  a  bullock  carrying  a  box  of  treasure.  He  drives  the  bullock  in  a  certain  direction,  in  order  that  he  may dishonestly take the treasure. As soon as the bullock begins to move, A has committed theft of the treasure.
texts.text: ( c )  A  meets  a  bullock  carrying  a  box  of  treasure.  He  drives  the  bullock  in  a  certain  direction,  in  order  that  he  may dishonestly take the treasure. As soon as the bullock begins to move, A has committed theft of the treasure.

texts.label: footnote
texts.orig: 1. Subs. by Act 26 of 1955, s. 117 and the Sch., for 'transportation for life' (w.e.f. 1 -1-1956).
texts.text: 1. Subs. by Act 26 of 1955, s. 117 and the Sch., for 'transportation for life' (w.e.f. 1 -1-1956).

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( d )  A  being  Z's  servant,  and  entrusted  by  Z  with  the  care  of  Z's  plate,  dishonestly  runs  away  with  the plate,  without  Z's consent. A has committed theft.
texts.text: ( d )  A  being  Z's  servant,  and  entrusted  by  Z  with  the  care  of  Z's  plate,  dishonestly  runs  away  with  the plate,  without  Z's consent. A has committed theft.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( e )  Z,  going  on  a  journey,  entrusts  his  plate  to  A,  the  keeper  of  a  warehouse,  till  Z  shall  return. A  carries  the  plate  to  a goldsmith and sells it. Here the plate was not in Z's possession. It could not therefore be taken out of Z's possession, and A has not committed theft, though he may have committed criminal breach of trust.
texts.text: ( e )  Z,  going  on  a  journey,  entrusts  his  plate  to  A,  the  keeper  of  a  warehouse,  till  Z  shall  return. A  carries  the  plate  to  a goldsmith and sells it. Here the plate was not in Z's possession. It could not therefore be taken out of Z's possession, and A has not committed theft, though he may have committed criminal breach of trust.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( f )  A  finds  a  ring  belonging  to Z  on  a  table  in the  house  which  Z  occupies.  Here  the  ring  is  in Z's  possession,  and  if  A dishonestly removes it, A commits theft.
texts.text: ( f )  A  finds  a  ring  belonging  to Z  on  a  table  in the  house  which  Z  occupies.  Here  the  ring  is  in Z's  possession,  and  if  A dishonestly removes it, A commits theft.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( g ) A finds a ring lying on the highroad, not in the possession of any person. A, by taking it, commits no theft, though he may commit criminal misappropriation of property.
texts.text: ( g ) A finds a ring lying on the highroad, not in the possession of any person. A, by taking it, commits no theft, though he may commit criminal misappropriation of property.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( h ) A sees a ring belonging to Z lying on a table in Z's house. Not venturing to misappropriate the ring immediately for fear of  search  and  detection,  A  hides  the  ring  in  a  place  where  it  is  highly  improbable  that  it  will  ever  be  found  by  Z,  with  the intention of taking the ring from the hiding place and selling it when the loss is forgotten. Here A, at the time of first moving the ring, commits theft.
texts.text: ( h ) A sees a ring belonging to Z lying on a table in Z's house. Not venturing to misappropriate the ring immediately for fear of  search  and  detection,  A  hides  the  ring  in  a  place  where  it  is  highly  improbable  that  it  will  ever  be  found  by  Z,  with  the intention of taking the ring from the hiding place and selling it when the loss is forgotten. Here A, at the time of first moving the ring, commits theft.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( i ) A delivers his watch to Z, a jeweller, to be regulated. Z carries it to his shop. A, not owing to the jeweller any debt for which the jeweller might lawfully detain the watch as a security, enters the shop openly, takes his watch by force out of Z's hand, and carries it away. Here A, though he may have committed criminal trespass and assault, has not committed theft, inasmuch as what he did was not done dishonestly.
texts.text: ( i ) A delivers his watch to Z, a jeweller, to be regulated. Z carries it to his shop. A, not owing to the jeweller any debt for which the jeweller might lawfully detain the watch as a security, enters the shop openly, takes his watch by force out of Z's hand, and carries it away. Here A, though he may have committed criminal trespass and assault, has not committed theft, inasmuch as what he did was not done dishonestly.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( j ) If A owes money to Z for repairing the watch, and if Z retains the watch lawfully as a security for the debt, and A takes the watch out of Z's possession, with the intention of depriving Z of the property as a security for his debt, he commits theft, inasmuch as he takes it dishonestly.
texts.text: ( j ) If A owes money to Z for repairing the watch, and if Z retains the watch lawfully as a security for the debt, and A takes the watch out of Z's possession, with the intention of depriving Z of the property as a security for his debt, he commits theft, inasmuch as he takes it dishonestly.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( k ) Again, if A, having pawned his watch to Z, takes it out of Z's possession without Z's consent, not having paid what he borrowed on the watch, he commits theft, though the watch is his own property inasmuch as he takes it dishonestly.
texts.text: ( k ) Again, if A, having pawned his watch to Z, takes it out of Z's possession without Z's consent, not having paid what he borrowed on the watch, he commits theft, though the watch is his own property inasmuch as he takes it dishonestly.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( l )  A  takes  an  article  belonging  to  Z  out  of  Z's  possession  without  Z's  consent,  with  the  intention  of  keeping  it  until  he obtains money from Z as a reward for its restoration. Here A takes dishonestly; A has therefor committed theft.
texts.text: ( l )  A  takes  an  article  belonging  to  Z  out  of  Z's  possession  without  Z's  consent,  with  the  intention  of  keeping  it  until  he obtains money from Z as a reward for its restoration. Here A takes dishonestly; A has therefor committed theft.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( m )  A,  being  on  friendly  terms  with  Z,  goes  into  Z's  library  in  Z's  absence,  and  takes  away  a  book  without  Z's  express consent for the purpose merely of reading it, and with the intention of returning it. Here, it is probable that A may have conceived that he had Z's implied consent to use Z's book. If this was A's impression, A has not committed theft.
texts.text: ( m )  A,  being  on  friendly  terms  with  Z,  goes  into  Z's  library  in  Z's  absence,  and  takes  away  a  book  without  Z's  express consent for the purpose merely of reading it, and with the intention of returning it. Here, it is probable that A may have conceived that he had Z's implied consent to use Z's book. If this was A's impression, A has not committed theft.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( n ) A asks charity from Z's wife. She gives A money, food and clothes, which A knows to belong to Z her husband. Here it is probable that A may conceive that Z's wife is authorised to give away alms. If this was A's impression, A has not committed theft.
texts.text: ( n ) A asks charity from Z's wife. She gives A money, food and clothes, which A knows to belong to Z her husband. Here it is probable that A may conceive that Z's wife is authorised to give away alms. If this was A's impression, A has not committed theft.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( o ) A is the paramour of Z's wife. She gives a valuable property, which A knows to belong to her husband Z, and to be such property as she has not authority from Z to give. If A takes the property dishonestly, he commits theft.
texts.text: ( o ) A is the paramour of Z's wife. She gives a valuable property, which A knows to belong to her husband Z, and to be such property as she has not authority from Z to give. If A takes the property dishonestly, he commits theft.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( p ) A, in good faith, believing property belonging to Z to be A's own property, takes that property out of B's possession. Here, as A does not take dishonestly, he does not commit theft.
texts.text: ( p ) A, in good faith, believing property belonging to Z to be A's own property, takes that property out of B's possession. Here, as A does not take dishonestly, he does not commit theft.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 379. Punishment for theft . -Whoever commits theft shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
texts.text: Punishment for theft . -Whoever commits theft shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 380. Theft in dwelling house, etc . -Whoever commits theft in any building, tent or vessel, which building, tent or vessel is used as a human dwelling, or used for the custody of property, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
texts.text: Theft in dwelling house, etc . -Whoever commits theft in any building, tent or vessel, which building, tent or vessel is used as a human dwelling, or used for the custody of property, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 381. Theft by clerk or servant of property in possession of master . -Whoever, being a clerk or servant, or being employed in the capacity of a clerk or servant, commits theft in respect of any property in the possession of his master or employer, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
texts.text: Theft by clerk or servant of property in possession of master . -Whoever, being a clerk or servant, or being employed in the capacity of a clerk or servant, commits theft in respect of any property in the possession of his master or employer, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 382.  Theft  after  preparation  made  for  causing  death,  hurt  or  restraint  in  order  to  the committing of the theft . -Whoever commits theft, having made preparation for causing death, or hurt, or restraint, or fear of death, or of hurt, or of restraint, to any person, in order to the committing of such theft,  or  in  order  to  the  effecting  of  his  escape  after  the  committing  of  such  theft,  or  in  order  to  the retaining of property taken by such theft, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
texts.text: Theft  after  preparation  made  for  causing  death,  hurt  or  restraint  in  order  to  the committing of the theft . -Whoever commits theft, having made preparation for causing death, or hurt, or restraint, or fear of death, or of hurt, or of restraint, to any person, in order to the committing of such theft,  or  in  order  to  the  effecting  of  his  escape  after  the  committing  of  such  theft,  or  in  order  to  the retaining of property taken by such theft, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Illustrations
texts.text: Illustrations

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( a ) A commits theft on property in Z's possession; and while committing this theft, he has a loaded pistol under his garment, having provided this pistol for the purpose of hurting Z in case  Z should resist. A has committed the offence defined in this section.
texts.text: ( a ) A commits theft on property in Z's possession; and while committing this theft, he has a loaded pistol under his garment, having provided this pistol for the purpose of hurting Z in case  Z should resist. A has committed the offence defined in this section.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( b )  A  picks Z's pocket, having posted several of his companions near him, in order that they may restrain Z, if Z should perceive what is passing and should resist, or should attempt to apprehend A. A has committed the offence defined in this section.
texts.text: ( b )  A  picks Z's pocket, having posted several of his companions near him, in order that they may restrain Z, if Z should perceive what is passing and should resist, or should attempt to apprehend A. A has committed the offence defined in this section.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Of Extortion
texts.text: Of Extortion

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 383. Extortion . -Whoever intentionally puts any person in fear of any injury to that person, or to any other, and thereby dishonestly induces the person so put in fear to deliver to any person any property, or valuable security or anything signed or sealed which may be converted into a valuable security, commits ' extortion ' .
texts.text: Extortion . -Whoever intentionally puts any person in fear of any injury to that person, or to any other, and thereby dishonestly induces the person so put in fear to deliver to any person any property, or valuable security or anything signed or sealed which may be converted into a valuable security, commits ' extortion ' .

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Illustrations
texts.text: Illustrations

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( a ) A threatens to publish a defamatory libel concerning Z unless Z gives him money. He thus induces Z to give him money. A has committed extortion.
texts.text: ( a ) A threatens to publish a defamatory libel concerning Z unless Z gives him money. He thus induces Z to give him money. A has committed extortion.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( b ) A threatens Z that he will keep Z's child in wrongful confinement, unless Z will sign and deliver to A a promissory note binding Z to pay certain monies to A. Z sings and delivers the note. A has committed extortion.
texts.text: ( b ) A threatens Z that he will keep Z's child in wrongful confinement, unless Z will sign and deliver to A a promissory note binding Z to pay certain monies to A. Z sings and delivers the note. A has committed extortion.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( c ) A threatens to send club-men to plough up Z's field unless Z will sign and deliver to B a bond binding Z under a penalty to deliver certain produce to B, and thereby induces Z to sign and deliver the bond. A has committed extortion.
texts.text: ( c ) A threatens to send club-men to plough up Z's field unless Z will sign and deliver to B a bond binding Z under a penalty to deliver certain produce to B, and thereby induces Z to sign and deliver the bond. A has committed extortion.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( d ) A, by putting Z in fear of grievous hurt, dishonestly induces Z to sign or affix his seal to a blank paper and deliver it to A. Z sings and delivers the paper to A. Here, as the paper so signed may be converted into a valuable security. A has committed extortion.
texts.text: ( d ) A, by putting Z in fear of grievous hurt, dishonestly induces Z to sign or affix his seal to a blank paper and deliver it to A. Z sings and delivers the paper to A. Here, as the paper so signed may be converted into a valuable security. A has committed extortion.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 384. Punishment for extortion . -Whoever commits extortion shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
texts.text: Punishment for extortion . -Whoever commits extortion shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 385. Putting person in fear of injury in order to commit extortion . -Whoever, in order to the committing of extortion, puts any person in fear, or attempts to put any person in fear, of any injury, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
texts.text: Putting person in fear of injury in order to commit extortion . -Whoever, in order to the committing of extortion, puts any person in fear, or attempts to put any person in fear, of any injury, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 386.  Extortion  by  putting  a  person  in  fear  of  death  or  grievous  hurt . -Whoever  commits extortion by putting any person in fear of death or of grievous hurt to that person or to any other, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
texts.text: Extortion  by  putting  a  person  in  fear  of  death  or  grievous  hurt . -Whoever  commits extortion by putting any person in fear of death or of grievous hurt to that person or to any other, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 387.  Putting  person  in  fear  of  death  or  of  grievous  hurt,  in  order  to  commit  extortion . -Whoever, in order to the committing of extortion, puts or attempts to put any person in fear of death or of grievous hurt to that person or to any other, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
texts.text: Putting  person  in  fear  of  death  or  of  grievous  hurt,  in  order  to  commit  extortion . -Whoever, in order to the committing of extortion, puts or attempts to put any person in fear of death or of grievous hurt to that person or to any other, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 388. Extortion by threat of accusation of an offence punishable with death or imprisonment for life, etc . -Whoever commits extortion by putting any person in fear of an accusation against that person or any other, of having committed or attempted to commit any offence punishable with death, or with 1 [imprisonment for life], or with imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, or of having attempted to induce any other person to commit such offence, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine; and, if the offence be one punishable under section 377 of this Code, may be punished with 1 [imprisonment for life].
texts.text: Extortion by threat of accusation of an offence punishable with death or imprisonment for life, etc . -Whoever commits extortion by putting any person in fear of an accusation against that person or any other, of having committed or attempted to commit any offence punishable with death, or with 1 [imprisonment for life], or with imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, or of having attempted to induce any other person to commit such offence, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine; and, if the offence be one punishable under section 377 of this Code, may be punished with 1 [imprisonment for life].

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 389. Putting person in fear or accusation of offence, in order to commit extortion . -Whoever, in order to the committing of extortion, puts or attempts to put any person in fear of an accusation, against that person or any other, of having committed, or attempted to commit, an offence punishable with death or with 1 [imprisonment for life], or with imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine; and, if the offence be punishable under section 377 of this Code, may be punished with 1 [imprisonment for life].
texts.text: Putting person in fear or accusation of offence, in order to commit extortion . -Whoever, in order to the committing of extortion, puts or attempts to put any person in fear of an accusation, against that person or any other, of having committed, or attempted to commit, an offence punishable with death or with 1 [imprisonment for life], or with imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine; and, if the offence be punishable under section 377 of this Code, may be punished with 1 [imprisonment for life].

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Of Robbery and Dacoity
texts.text: Of Robbery and Dacoity

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 390. Robbery . -In all robbery there is either theft or extortion.
texts.text: Robbery . -In all robbery there is either theft or extortion.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: When  theft  is  robbery . -Theft  is ' robbery ' if,  in  order  to  the  committing  of  the  theft,  or  in committing the theft, or in carrying away or attempting to carry away property obtained by the theft, the
texts.text: When  theft  is  robbery . -Theft  is ' robbery ' if,  in  order  to  the  committing  of  the  theft,  or  in committing the theft, or in carrying away or attempting to carry away property obtained by the theft, the

texts.label: footnote
texts.orig: 1. Subs. by Act 26 of 1955, s. 117 and the Sch., for 'transportation for life' (w.e.f. 1 -1-1956).
texts.text: 1. Subs. by Act 26 of 1955, s. 117 and the Sch., for 'transportation for life' (w.e.f. 1 -1-1956).

texts.label: text
texts.orig: offender,  for  that  end  voluntarily  causes  or  attempts  to  cause  to  any  person  death  or  hurt  or  wrongful restraint, or fear of instant death or of instant hurt, or of instant wrongful restraint.
texts.text: offender,  for  that  end  voluntarily  causes  or  attempts  to  cause  to  any  person  death  or  hurt  or  wrongful restraint, or fear of instant death or of instant hurt, or of instant wrongful restraint.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: When extortion is robbery . -Extortion is ' robbery ' if  the offender, at the time of committing the extortion, is in the presence of the person put in fear, and commits the extortion by putting that person in fear of instant death, of instant hurt, or of instant wrongful restraint to that person or to some other person, and, by so putting in fear, induces the person so put in fear then and there to deliver up the thing extorted.
texts.text: When extortion is robbery . -Extortion is ' robbery ' if  the offender, at the time of committing the extortion, is in the presence of the person put in fear, and commits the extortion by putting that person in fear of instant death, of instant hurt, or of instant wrongful restraint to that person or to some other person, and, by so putting in fear, induces the person so put in fear then and there to deliver up the thing extorted.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Explanation . -The offender is said to be present if he is sufficiently near to put the other person in fear of instant death, of instant hurt, or of instant wrongful restraint.
texts.text: Explanation . -The offender is said to be present if he is sufficiently near to put the other person in fear of instant death, of instant hurt, or of instant wrongful restraint.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Illustrations
texts.text: Illustrations

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( a )  A  holds  Z  down,  and  fraudulently  takes  Z's  money  and  jewels  from  Z's  clothes,  without  Z's  consent.  Here  A  has committed theft, and, in order to the committing of that theft, has voluntarily  caused wrongful restraint to Z. A has therefore committed robbery.
texts.text: ( a )  A  holds  Z  down,  and  fraudulently  takes  Z's  money  and  jewels  from  Z's  clothes,  without  Z's  consent.  Here  A  has committed theft, and, in order to the committing of that theft, has voluntarily  caused wrongful restraint to Z. A has therefore committed robbery.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( b ) A meets Z on the high road, shows a pistol, and demands Z's purse. Z, in consequence, surrenders his purse. Here A has extorted the purse from Z by putting him in fear of instant hurt, and being at the time of committing the extortion in his presence. A has therefore committed robbery.
texts.text: ( b ) A meets Z on the high road, shows a pistol, and demands Z's purse. Z, in consequence, surrenders his purse. Here A has extorted the purse from Z by putting him in fear of instant hurt, and being at the time of committing the extortion in his presence. A has therefore committed robbery.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( c ) A meets Z and Z's child on the high road. A takes the child, and threatens to filing it down a precipice, unless Z delivers his purse. Z, in consequence, delivers his purse. Here A has extorted the purse from Z, by causing Z to be in fear of instant hurt to the child who is there present. A has therefore committed robbery on Z.
texts.text: ( c ) A meets Z and Z's child on the high road. A takes the child, and threatens to filing it down a precipice, unless Z delivers his purse. Z, in consequence, delivers his purse. Here A has extorted the purse from Z, by causing Z to be in fear of instant hurt to the child who is there present. A has therefore committed robbery on Z.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( d ) A ob tains property from Z by saying ' Your child is in the hands of my gang, and will be put to death unless you send us ten thousand rupees ' . This is extortion, and punishable as such: but it is not robbery, unless Z is put in fear of the instant death of his child.
texts.text: ( d ) A ob tains property from Z by saying ' Your child is in the hands of my gang, and will be put to death unless you send us ten thousand rupees ' . This is extortion, and punishable as such: but it is not robbery, unless Z is put in fear of the instant death of his child.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 391. Dacoity . -When five or more persons conjointly commit or  attempt to commit a robbery, or where  the  whole  number  of  persons  conjointly  committing  or  attempting  to  commit  a  robbery,  and persons  present  and  aiding  such  commission  or  attempt,  amount  to  five  or  more,  every  person  so committing, attempting or aiding, is said to commit ' dacoity ' .
texts.text: Dacoity . -When five or more persons conjointly commit or  attempt to commit a robbery, or where  the  whole  number  of  persons  conjointly  committing  or  attempting  to  commit  a  robbery,  and persons  present  and  aiding  such  commission  or  attempt,  amount  to  five  or  more,  every  person  so committing, attempting or aiding, is said to commit ' dacoity ' .

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 392.  Punishment  for  robbery . -Whoever  commits  robbery  shall  be  punished  with  rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine; and, if the robbery be committed on the highway between sunset and sunrise, the imprisonment may be extended to fourteen years.
texts.text: Punishment  for  robbery . -Whoever  commits  robbery  shall  be  punished  with  rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine; and, if the robbery be committed on the highway between sunset and sunrise, the imprisonment may be extended to fourteen years.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 393. Attempt to commit robbery . -Whoever attempts to commit robbery shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
texts.text: Attempt to commit robbery . -Whoever attempts to commit robbery shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 394.  Voluntarily  causing  hurt  in  committing  robbery . -If  any  person,  in  committing  or  in attempting  to  commit  robbery,  voluntarily  causes  hurt,  such  person,  and  any  other  person  jointly concerned in committing or attempting to commit such robbery, shall be punished with 1 [imprisonment for life], or with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
texts.text: Voluntarily  causing  hurt  in  committing  robbery . -If  any  person,  in  committing  or  in attempting  to  commit  robbery,  voluntarily  causes  hurt,  such  person,  and  any  other  person  jointly concerned in committing or attempting to commit such robbery, shall be punished with 1 [imprisonment for life], or with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 395. Punishment for dacoity . -Whoever commits dacoity shall be punished with 1 [imprisonment for life], or with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
texts.text: Punishment for dacoity . -Whoever commits dacoity shall be punished with 1 [imprisonment for life], or with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 396.  Dacoity  with  murder . -If  any  one  of  five  or  more  persons,  who  are  conjointly  committing dacoity,  commits murder in so committing dacoity,  every one of those persons shall be punished with death, or 1 [imprisonment for life], or rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
texts.text: Dacoity  with  murder . -If  any  one  of  five  or  more  persons,  who  are  conjointly  committing dacoity,  commits murder in so committing dacoity,  every one of those persons shall be punished with death, or 1 [imprisonment for life], or rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 397.  Robbery,  or  dacoity,  with  attempt  to  cause  death  or  grievous  hurt . -If,  at  the  time  of committing  robbery  or  dacoity,  the  offender  uses  any  deadly  weapon,  or  causes  grievous  hurt  to  any person,  or  attempts  to  cause  death  or  grievous  hurt  to  any  person,  the  imprisonment  with  which  such offender shall be punished shall not be less than seven years.
texts.text: Robbery,  or  dacoity,  with  attempt  to  cause  death  or  grievous  hurt . -If,  at  the  time  of committing  robbery  or  dacoity,  the  offender  uses  any  deadly  weapon,  or  causes  grievous  hurt  to  any person,  or  attempts  to  cause  death  or  grievous  hurt  to  any  person,  the  imprisonment  with  which  such offender shall be punished shall not be less than seven years.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 398. Attempt to commit robbery or dacoitywhen armed with deadly weapon . -If, at the time of attempting  to  commit  robbery  or  dacoity,  the  offender  is  armed  with  any  deadly  weapon,  the imprisonment with which such offender shall be punished shall not be less than seven years.
texts.text: Attempt to commit robbery or dacoitywhen armed with deadly weapon . -If, at the time of attempting  to  commit  robbery  or  dacoity,  the  offender  is  armed  with  any  deadly  weapon,  the imprisonment with which such offender shall be punished shall not be less than seven years.

texts.label: footnote
texts.orig: 1. Subs. by Act 26 of 1955, s. 117 and the Sch., for 'transportation for life' (w.e.f. 1 -1-1956).
texts.text: 1. Subs. by Act 26 of 1955, s. 117 and the Sch., for 'transportation for life' (w.e.f. 1 -1-1956).

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 399.  Making  preparation  to  commit  dacoity . -Whoever  makes  any  preparation  for  committing dacoity, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
texts.text: Making  preparation  to  commit  dacoity . -Whoever  makes  any  preparation  for  committing dacoity, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 400. Punishment for belonging to gang of dacoits . -Whoever, at any time after the passing of this Act, shall belong to a gang of persons associated for the purpose of habitually committing dacoity, shall be punished with 1 [imprisonment for life], or with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
texts.text: Punishment for belonging to gang of dacoits . -Whoever, at any time after the passing of this Act, shall belong to a gang of persons associated for the purpose of habitually committing dacoity, shall be punished with 1 [imprisonment for life], or with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 401. Punishment for belonging to gang of thieves . -Whoever, at any time after the passing of this Act,  shall  belong  to  any  wandering  or  other  gang  of  persons  associated  for  the  purpose  of  habitually committing theft or robbery, and not being a gang of thugs or  dacoits,  shall  be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
texts.text: Punishment for belonging to gang of thieves . -Whoever, at any time after the passing of this Act,  shall  belong  to  any  wandering  or  other  gang  of  persons  associated  for  the  purpose  of  habitually committing theft or robbery, and not being a gang of thugs or  dacoits,  shall  be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 402. Assembling for purpose of committing dacoity . -Whoever, at any time after the passing of this Act, shall be one of five or more persons assembled for the purpose of committing dacoity, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
texts.text: Assembling for purpose of committing dacoity . -Whoever, at any time after the passing of this Act, shall be one of five or more persons assembled for the purpose of committing dacoity, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Of Criminal Misappropriation of Property
texts.text: Of Criminal Misappropriation of Property

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 403. Dishonest misappropriation of property . -Whoever dishonestly misappropriates or converts to  his  own  use  any  movable  property,  shall  be  punished  with  imprisonment  of either description for  a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
texts.text: Dishonest misappropriation of property . -Whoever dishonestly misappropriates or converts to  his  own  use  any  movable  property,  shall  be  punished  with  imprisonment  of either description for  a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Illustrations
texts.text: Illustrations

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( a )  A  takes  property  belonging to Z  out  of  Z's  possession,  in  good  faith  believing  at  the  time  when  he  takes  it,  that  the property belongs to himself. A is not guilty of theft; but if A, after discovering his mistake, dishonestly appropriates the property to his own use, he is guilty of an offence under this section.
texts.text: ( a )  A  takes  property  belonging to Z  out  of  Z's  possession,  in  good  faith  believing  at  the  time  when  he  takes  it,  that  the property belongs to himself. A is not guilty of theft; but if A, after discovering his mistake, dishonestly appropriates the property to his own use, he is guilty of an offence under this section.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( b )  A,  being  on  friendly  terms  with  Z,  goes  into  Z's  library  in  Z's  absence,  and  takes  away  a  book  without  Z's  express consent. Here, if A was under the impression that he had Z's implied consent to take the book for the purpose of reading it, A has not committed theft. But, if A afterwards sells the book for his own benefit, he is guilty of an offence under this section.
texts.text: ( b )  A,  being  on  friendly  terms  with  Z,  goes  into  Z's  library  in  Z's  absence,  and  takes  away  a  book  without  Z's  express consent. Here, if A was under the impression that he had Z's implied consent to take the book for the purpose of reading it, A has not committed theft. But, if A afterwards sells the book for his own benefit, he is guilty of an offence under this section.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( c ) A and B, being, joint owners of a horse, A takes the horse out of B's possession, intending to use it. Here, as A has a right to use the horse, he does not dishonestly misappropriate it. But, if A sells the horse and appropriates the whole proceeds to his own use, he is guilty of an offence under this section.
texts.text: ( c ) A and B, being, joint owners of a horse, A takes the horse out of B's possession, intending to use it. Here, as A has a right to use the horse, he does not dishonestly misappropriate it. But, if A sells the horse and appropriates the whole proceeds to his own use, he is guilty of an offence under this section.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Explanation 1 . -A dishonest misappropriation for a time only is a misappropriation with the meaning of this section.
texts.text: Explanation 1 . -A dishonest misappropriation for a time only is a misappropriation with the meaning of this section.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Illustration
texts.text: Illustration

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: A finds a Government promissory note belonging to Z, bearing a blank endorsement. A, knowing that the note belongs to Z, pledges it with a banker as a security or a loan, intending at a future time to restore it to Z. A has committed an offence under this section.
texts.text: A finds a Government promissory note belonging to Z, bearing a blank endorsement. A, knowing that the note belongs to Z, pledges it with a banker as a security or a loan, intending at a future time to restore it to Z. A has committed an offence under this section.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Explanation 2 . -A person who finds property not in the possession of any other person, and takes such  property  for  the  purpose  of  protecting  it  for,  or  of  restoring  it  to,  the  owner,  does  not  take  or misappropriate it dishonestly, and is not guilty of an offence; but he is guilty of the offence above defined, if he appropriates it to his own use, when he knows or has the means of discovering the owner, or before he  has  used  reasonable  means  to  discover  and  give  notice  to  the  owner  and  has  kept  the  property  a reasonable time to enable the owner to claim it.
texts.text: Explanation 2 . -A person who finds property not in the possession of any other person, and takes such  property  for  the  purpose  of  protecting  it  for,  or  of  restoring  it  to,  the  owner,  does  not  take  or misappropriate it dishonestly, and is not guilty of an offence; but he is guilty of the offence above defined, if he appropriates it to his own use, when he knows or has the means of discovering the owner, or before he  has  used  reasonable  means  to  discover  and  give  notice  to  the  owner  and  has  kept  the  property  a reasonable time to enable the owner to claim it.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: What are reasonable means or what is a reasonable time in such a case, is a question of fact.
texts.text: What are reasonable means or what is a reasonable time in such a case, is a question of fact.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: It is not necessary that the finder should know who is the owner of the property, or that any particular person is the owner of it; it is sufficient if, at the time of appropriating it, he does not believe it to be his own property, or in good faith believe that the real owner cannot be found.
texts.text: It is not necessary that the finder should know who is the owner of the property, or that any particular person is the owner of it; it is sufficient if, at the time of appropriating it, he does not believe it to be his own property, or in good faith believe that the real owner cannot be found.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Illustrations
texts.text: Illustrations

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( a )  A  finds  a  rupee  on  the  high  road,  not  knowing  to  whom  the  rupee  belongs,  A  picks  up  the  rupee.  Here  A  has  not committed the offence defined in this section.
texts.text: ( a )  A  finds  a  rupee  on  the  high  road,  not  knowing  to  whom  the  rupee  belongs,  A  picks  up  the  rupee.  Here  A  has  not committed the offence defined in this section.

texts.label: footnote
texts.orig: 1. Subs. by Act 26 of 1955, s. 117 and the Sch., for 'transportation for life' (w.e.f. 1 -1-1956).
texts.text: 1. Subs. by Act 26 of 1955, s. 117 and the Sch., for 'transportation for life' (w.e.f. 1 -1-1956).

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( b ) A finds a letter on the road, containing a bank note. From the direction and contents of the letter he learns to whom the note belongs. He appropriates the note. He is guilty of an offence under this section.
texts.text: ( b ) A finds a letter on the road, containing a bank note. From the direction and contents of the letter he learns to whom the note belongs. He appropriates the note. He is guilty of an offence under this section.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( c ) A finds a cheque payable to bearer. He can form no conjecture as to the person who has lost the cheque. But the name of the person, who has drawn the cheque, appears. A knows that this person can direct him to the person in whose favour the cheque was drawn. A appropriates the cheque without attempting to discover the owner. He is guilty of an offence under this section.
texts.text: ( c ) A finds a cheque payable to bearer. He can form no conjecture as to the person who has lost the cheque. But the name of the person, who has drawn the cheque, appears. A knows that this person can direct him to the person in whose favour the cheque was drawn. A appropriates the cheque without attempting to discover the owner. He is guilty of an offence under this section.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( d ) A sees Z drop his purse with money in it. A picks up the purse with the intention of restoring it to Z, but afterwards appropriates it to his own use. A has committed an offence under this section.
texts.text: ( d ) A sees Z drop his purse with money in it. A picks up the purse with the intention of restoring it to Z, but afterwards appropriates it to his own use. A has committed an offence under this section.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( e )  A  finds  a  purse  with  money,  not  knowing  to  whom  it  belongs;  he  afterwards  discovers  that  it  belongs  to  Z,  and appropriates it to his own use. A is guilty of an offence under this section.
texts.text: ( e )  A  finds  a  purse  with  money,  not  knowing  to  whom  it  belongs;  he  afterwards  discovers  that  it  belongs  to  Z,  and appropriates it to his own use. A is guilty of an offence under this section.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: ( f )  A  finds  a  valuable  ring,  not  knowing  to  whom  it  belongs.  A  sells  it  immediately  without  attempting  to  discover  the owner. A is guilty of an offence under this section.
texts.text: ( f )  A  finds  a  valuable  ring,  not  knowing  to  whom  it  belongs.  A  sells  it  immediately  without  attempting  to  discover  the owner. A is guilty of an offence under this section.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: 404. Dishonest misappropriation of property possessed by deceased person at the time of his death . -Whoever dishonestly misappropriates or converts to his own use property, knowing that such property was in the possession of a deceased person at the time of that person's decease, and has not since been  in  the  possession  of  any  person  legally  entitled  to  such  possession,  shall  be  punished  with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine, and if the offender at the time of such person's decease was employed by him as a clerk or servant, the imprisonment may extend to seven years.
texts.text: Dishonest misappropriation of property possessed by deceased person at the time of his death . -Whoever dishonestly misappropriates or converts to his own use property, knowing that such property was in the possession of a deceased person at the time of that person's decease, and has not since been  in  the  possession  of  any  person  legally  entitled  to  such  possession,  shall  be  punished  with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine, and if the offender at the time of such person's decease was employed by him as a clerk or servant, the imprisonment may extend to seven years.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Illustration
texts.text: Illustration

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Z dies  in  possession  of  furniture  and  money.  His  servant  A,  before  the  money  comes  into  the  possession  of  any  person entitled to such possession, dishonestly misappropriates it. A has committed the offence defined in this section.
texts.text: Z dies  in  possession  of  furniture  and  money.  His  servant  A,  before  the  money  comes  into  the  possession  of  any  person entitled to such possession, dishonestly misappropriates it. A has committed the offence defined in this section.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Of Criminal Breach of Trust
texts.text: Of Criminal Breach of Trust

texts.label: text
texts.orig: 405. Criminal breach of trust . -Whoever, being in any manner entrusted with property, or with any dominion  over  property,  dishonestly  misappropriates  or  converts  to  his  own  use  that  property,  or dishonestly uses or disposes of that property in violation of any direction of law prescribing the mode in which such trust is  to  be  discharged,  or  of  any  legal  contract,  express  or  implied,  which  he  has  made touching  the  discharge  of  such  trust,  or  wilfully  suffers  any  other  person  so  to  do,  commits ' criminal breach of trust ' .
texts.text: 405. Criminal breach of trust . -Whoever, being in any manner entrusted with property, or with any dominion  over  property,  dishonestly  misappropriates  or  converts  to  his  own  use  that  property,  or dishonestly uses or disposes of that property in violation of any direction of law prescribing the mode in which such trust is  to  be  discharged,  or  of  any  legal  contract,  express  or  implied,  which  he  has  made touching  the  discharge  of  such  trust,  or  wilfully  suffers  any  other  person  so  to  do,  commits ' criminal breach of trust ' .

texts.label: text
